title: FirstFT: Today's top stories
text:
How well did you keep up with the news this week? Take our quiz.

Joe Biden has doubled his goal for coronavirus vaccinations to 200m in his first 100 days in office, as he used his first presidential press conference to claim progress against the pandemic.

After waiting 64 days to meet formally with the White House press corps, the 78-year-old US president dismissed accusations that he had mishandled the migrant crisis and said he intended to run for re-election in 2024.

In an indication of his determination to fight for the rest of his sweeping agenda, including voting rights, Biden sent the strongest signal yet that he supported changes to Senate rules that would make it easier for legislation to pass without Republican support.

Next week Biden is expected to propose an additional $3tn in long-term spending on areas such as infrastructure, education and caregiving, to be at least partly financed by tax increases.

Coronavirus digest

  • EU divisions over vaccine distribution were laid bare at an online summit on Thursday as governments failed to agree on how to provide additional jabs to member states in need of emergency supplies.

  • India says it is “calibrating” its vaccine exports in an attempt to balance surging domestic demand with international orders but insists that it has not banned drug shipments.

  • New US jobless benefit claims fell to the lowest level of the pandemic. The Federal Reserve said it would lift restrictions on share buybacks and dividend payments for most US banks after June 30.

  • Oxford university has begun advertising for participants in an early-stage trial for a Covid-19 nasal spray vaccine developed with AstraZeneca. Meanwhile, Sweden is to resume administering the AstraZeneca jab for people aged 65 and over but the health scares around the vaccine have tested Europeans' confidence.

Comfort food is not an illusion, especially during lockdown. But too much, although helpful with anxiety, is unhealthy, writes John Gapper. Follow our live blog and sign up for our Coronavirus Business Update email.

In the news

Exclusive: Wall St banks set to take stakes in Mall of America JPMorgan Chase and Goldman Sachs are among the investors set to take a stake in America's largest shopping centre after its owner defaulted on another multibillion-dollar development in New Jersey. (FT)

Shipping groups contact US Navy over piracy threat Shipping companies from multiple countries have contacted the US Navy about the potentially elevated threat of piracy to rerouted vessels after a container ship ran aground and blocked the Suez Canal. Rescuers warned on Thursday that refloating the 220,000-tonne Ever Given could take “weeks”.

  • A strong gust of wind could have played a role in the blockage, writes Brendan Greeley — but in hydrodynamics size matters, and ships keep getting bigger. (FT)

WeWork to merge with Spac in $9bn deal The US office provider is to merge with blank-cheque company BowX Acquisition in a deal valued at $9bn. The merger will give WeWork a $1.3bn cash injection. The FT reported this week that WeWork made losses of $3.2bn last year.

  • The US Securities and Exchange Commission has asked Wall Street groups for information regarding listings of blank-cheque companies, intensifying regulatory scrutiny of the booming area. (FT)

Record $140bn raised in US junk bond market in first quarter Companies have issued $140bn in the US junk bond market over the past three months, outpacing a record dash for cash in the second quarter of 2020 when groups struggled to survive the coronavirus shock. The three biggest issuance quarters on record have all fallen in the past 12 months. (FT)

Tech executives grilled over US Capitol riots Facebook's Mark Zuckerberg, Twitter's Jack Dorsey and Google's Sundar Pichai were asked by US lawmakers on Thursday whether their platforms bore responsibility for the assault on the US Capitol on January 6. Only Dorsey gave an unequivocal “yes”. More important moments here. (FT, Reuters, Politico)

  • Amazon has told the Texas Supreme Court it is “not realistic” to expect the company to vet the products sold on its platform, arguing it was not to be held responsible when items bought on Amazon.com cause harm to consumers.

UK-US trade deal talks set to miss crucial deadline UK hopes of clinching a trade deal with the US — seen as one of the biggest prizes of Brexit — are facing a further setback as negotiators are set to miss a critical deadline for securing swift passage through Congress. (FT)

The day ahead

Economic data US personal income and consumer spending may fall in February. Also, the final reading of the University of Michigan's consumer sentiment index for March is expected. (WSJ)

WTO dispute body meets The World Trade Organization's dispute settlement body is due to consider an anti-dumping dispute with China, the Airbus-Boeing dispute and the crippled Appellate Body. (FT)

Kumho Petrochemical vote Shareholders in the world's largest producer of synthetic rubber, which include BlackRock, HSBC and Vanguard, vote today on an overhaul of the company's governance. The activist battle has pitted a chaebol princeling against his estranged uncle, the group's chair and chief executive. (FT)

50th anniversary of Bangladesh India's prime minister Narendra Modi visits neighbouring Bangladesh on Friday to mark its 50th anniversary. Pope Francis has also congratulated the nation on its 50 years of independence. (Times of India, Vatican News)

Join FT Climate Capital journalists on Wednesday for a discussion on how bankers and investors are financing a green global recovery. We ask how economic growth can be compatible with climate action and how quickly fossil-fuelled economies can achieve net zero. Sign up here.

What else we're reading

The return of the inflation spectre Unexpectedly high inflation would raise interest rates, destabilise exchange rates, ignite unrest in labour markets, push the highly indebted towards default and destabilise asset markets. But is it a plausible threat? And what would it mean if it did return, asks Martin Wolf.

Should we feel bad for junior investment bankers? An internal survey of first-year Goldman Sachs analysts provided a glimpse into life at the bottom of the ladder. Due Diligence, our corporate finance newsletter, rounds up reaction to this week's viral sensation. “You're on a virtual leash 24/7,” one junior analyst told DD. (FT)

Central bankers' crypto experiments should alert investors The Federal Reserve and others are trying a mild version of the “If you can't beat 'em, join 'em” strategy, writes Gillian Tett. Instead of ignoring bitcoin or Facebook, they hope to harness some of their innovative ideas. (FT)

Will superstar employees be offshored? High-skilled jobs are being offshored out of leading cities to the rest of the world. Like so many Covid-19 changes, what began as an emergency response may solidify into permanence. But a scary thought: if you can do your job from anywhere, someone anywhere can do your job, writes Simon Kuper. (FT)

Erdogan sacrifices women's protection in appeal to conservatives President Recep Tayyip Erdogan has withdrawn from the Istanbul convention to combat violence against women — which in 2012, his country was the first to ratify. Women's rights have become the latest battleground in his war to consolidate power as the economy falters, warns Leyla Boulton. (FT)

Video of the day

US shifts policy but the Yemen war is not over The FT's Katrina Manson discusses Joe Biden's plan to end the war in Yemen with former US ambassador Gerald Feierstein and Amanda Catanzano from the International Rescue Committee charity. (FT)

Source: Gordon Smith, Jennifer Creery and Emily Goldberg 2021 'FirstFT: Today's top stories' FT.com 26 March. Used under licence from the Financial Times. © The Financial Times Limited 2021. All Rights Reserved.
